at.label: fn_set
at.comment:
entry vector handler for
BASIC command "SET"

at.label: fn_reset
at.comment:
entry vector handler for
BASIC command "RESET"

SET: determine memory location to
change check: y coordinate <= 64

multiply y coordinate with
32 (bytes per row)

get x coordinate and divide by
4 (pixels per byte)
store as counter for upcoming DJNZ

fill C with 1 bits as reservoir for
shifting in upcoming RRC instructions

get current 3 bit color code
(in high nybble)
drop 3rd bit, shift others to MSB

loop: #B iterations
[NOTE: here is a performance bug:
If A=0 (which occurs for every 4th pixel),
the loop wastes time by iterating 256 times,
while it would not needed to be entered at all.]

entry vector handler for
BASIC command "CLS"

entry vector handler for
inactivated BASIC command with token 0xa6
duration code 3: dotted 16th note (#3 time units)
duration code 5: dotted 8th note (#6 time units)
duration code 6: quarter note (#8 time units)
duration code 7: dotted quarter note (#12 time units)
duration code 8: half note (#16 time units)
duration code 9: dotted half note (#24 time units)

cout callback before device branch
(screen/printer/cassette), character in reg. A

entry for cout routine for screen device,
character in reg. A

entry for cout routine for print device,
character in reg. A

actual cout routine for print device,
character in reg. C

query printer status,
result in reg. A, bit 0 (0=ready, 1=busy)

push subroutine parameters onto stack:
DE=source, HL=target, 0x78af=count
number parser: end of number token reached
number parser: digit found; handle it
number parser: add next parsed digit to integer value
check: number too large to fit in signed integer?
number in range; store it; continue parsing
number too large for signed integer

check for printing group separator "," or
decimal separator "." while printing a number

print number decimal separator "."
and prepare printing mantissa

print integer value stored at
0x7921 as decimal

outer loop for repeated printing of
digits until decimal representation of
integer is complete

inner loop for repeated subtraction for
determining next decimal digit of integer

at.label: token_tbl
at.header:
---- START BASIC TOKENS TABLE ----
(first character of each token marked by bit 8=1)

at.comment:
vector to handler for token 0xae
(hidden, equals cold reset)

appended to error message when
line number available

at.label: emit_err
at.comment:
error code in reg E
flush output

at.label: rst18_impl
at.header:
---- implementation of RST 18H ----
Compare unsigned DE & HL register pairs
Result:
* HL < DE => C=1
* HL >= DE => C=0
* HL != DE => Z=0
* HL == DE => Z=1

at.label: rst08_impl
at.header:
---- implementation of RST 08H ----
parse token char
* HL points to current char of string to check.
* The expected char to be parsed is fetched from
memory location immediately following the RST command.
* On failure, jump to routine that prints "?syntax error"
and continues editing.
* On success, control flow will return to two bytes after
previous RST 08H command (such as to skip the char data
byte to be compared).

at.label: rst10_impl
at.header:
---- START implementation of RST 10H ----
Look ahead next character in parse input
(BASIC parser)
* if char is higher than the digit "9",
then return with C=0,
* else if char is any of white space (20h),
tab (09h) or LF (0ah), then skip that char
and try again with next char,
* else set C=1 if and only if char is a digit
and set Z=1 if and only if char is 0
and set S=0
and set H=1 if and only if (char & 0fh)=0fh
and set P=1 if char contains even # of 1s
and set N=1
* HL points to previous char
* skip 09h and 0bh
* return char in register A
* return C=0 if alphabetic char
* return C=1 if alphanumeric char

at.comment:
handler for token 0x93 ("REM")
handler for token 0x95 ("ELSE")

at.label: rst20_impl
at.header:
---- START implementation of RST 20H ----
Return the number of parameters to be
copied for a subroutine call minus 3,
and set the C flag if the returned
number is smaller than 5

at.comment:
Print \0-terminated
String with special handling for
surrounding quote characters
Parameters: HL = start address of
string
no => exit with function code error
yes => exit with function code error
no => exit with function code error
*2 for index into table of shorts
add index for entry in that table
base address of waves per time table
add index for entry in that table
load waves per time into DE
*1 for index into table of waves per time
add index for entry in that table
end of current sound: enable IRQs again
get next input char, if any
add index for entry in that table

at.label: rst38_impl
at.header: ---- START implementation of RST 38H ----
at.comment: IRQ handler for key press / kbd matrix scan

screen editor: check for key press &
handle key press (e.g. edit current line)

at.label: cout
at.comment:
character out main entry
switch to MODE(0) if in MODE(1)
mark char in reg A for output in
screen buffer

at.label: cout_ctrl
at.comment:
CTRL char => wait until
screen print buffer is empty

at.label: cout_buf_write
at.header:
---- START critical section ----
put char into screen print buffer
after that wait until IRQ has consumed the buffer

at.label: irq_scr_buf_cpy
at.header:
---- START IRQ Handler Screen Buffer Copy ----
copy screen buffer chars to video RAM and clear the buffer

at.footer: ---- END IRQ Handler Screen Buffer Copy ----

at.label: kbdin
at.comment:
screen editor: handle key press
(e.g. edit current line)

at.label: cursor_right
at.comment:
CHR$(9) / CHR$(25):
move cursor one column to the right

at.label: cursor_left
at.comment:
CHR$(8) / CHR$(24):
move cursor one column to the left

at.label: cursor_up
at.comment:
CHR$(27):
move cursor one line up

at.label: cursor_down
at.comment:
CHR$(10):
move cursor one line down

at.label: cursor_home
at.comment:
CHR$(28):
move cursor to left upper corner

at.label: cursor_bottom
at.comment:
move cursor to first column of
bottom line

I/O mask value with
speaker in idle state again

at.label: cass_cout
at.header:
---- START character out (1 byte) to cassette port ----
* start with short cycle (via 3542h)
* for each of the 8 bits of the byte,
starting with the uppermost bit, do:
* if bit is 1, then produce two
short cycles (via 3542h),
* otherwise (bit is 0) produce one
long cycle (via 352bh)

at.footer: ---- END character out (1 byte) to cassette port ----

at.label: cass_long_cycle
at.header:
---- START cassette out: long cycle ----
Cassette out: Long cycle
Status "11" for ca. 128s
(~470 CPU clock cycles), then
status "00" for ca. 128s
(~461 CPU clock cycles),
then goto 3524h to continue with next
bit of the current byte to write

at.label: cass_short_cycle
at.header:
---- START cassette out: short cycle ----
Cassette out: Short cyle
Status "11" for ca. 64s
(~230 CPU clock cycles), then
status "00" for ca. 64s
(~230 CPU clock cycles)

at.label: cass_wrt_hdr
at.header: ---- START cassette out: write file header ----

at.comment:
write value 0x80 255 times, but
abort on key press "BREAK"

write value 0xfe 5 times, but
abort on key press "BREAK"

write value of register C, but
abort on key press "BREAK"
write file name into file header

copy file name (w/o surrounding quotes)
from (HL) to (DE), DE=0x7a9d

add trailing 0-byte to file name and
save file name length

at.footer: ---- END cassette out: write file header ----

at.label: cass_prepare_scr
at.header: ---- START prepare screen for CLOAD / CRUN / VERIFY ----

at.comment: move cursor to lower right corner

bottom line joined with previous line as
double line?
yes => decouple bottom line from previous line

at.footer: ---- END prepare screen for CLOAD / CRUN / VERIFY ----

at.comment: got no valid bit => continue waiting

shared code for CLOAD, CRUN and VERIFY;
uses address 0x7839 to distinguish mode
call routine for printing status line

wait for cassette in value "0", but time out
after 0x0800 loop iterations
still get "0", or just got jitter?
just jitter => wait again for stable "0"
still get "0", or just got jitter?
just jitter => wait again for stable "0"

test if cassette in value keeps "1"
for at least 0x5a loop iterations
still get "0", or just got jitter?
still get "0", or just got jitter?

at.label: cass_prt_status
at.header: ---- START print status message in bottom line ----

at.comment: load video screen address of bottom line

at.footer: ---- END print status message in bottom line ----

at.comment:
jump to actual status printing routine
(will return to caller of caller)

at.label: graf_set
at.header:
---- START SET(x, y) ----
function for setting a pixel on
the graphics screen
Register DE contains the pre-computed
memory address to change.
Register C contains the pre-computed
AND bit mask of those bits to leave
unchanged.
Register A contains the code of current
color (i.e. the bits to set) in those
2 bits to bet set; all other bits are 0
(i.e. it can be used as OR bist mask).
NOTE: The code unneccessarily performs
two write accesses to the video buffer,
first effectively doing an UNSET(x, y),
and then writing the final, correct value

at.comment: write the UNSET(x, y) value into video RAM
write SET(x, y) value into video RAM

at.label: kbd_scan_brk
kbd_chk_brk
at.header:
---- START check for "BREAK" ----
abort CLOAD / CRUN / VERIFY, if
"BREAK" is pressed

at.comment: kick off cassette command stack frame

at.label: cass_cout
at.header: ---- START cout for cassette ----

at.label: prt_err
at.header:
---- START print error message ----
error code in register E

at.footer:
---- END print error message ----
NOTE: There is no stop marker (value >=0x80) behind
the last error code message "DISK COMMAND"
(error code 0x2c), such that this subroutine will print
too many chars for that message.

at.label: err_msg_tbl
at.header:
---- START ERROR MESSAGES TABLE ----
(first character of each message marked by bit 8=1)
error codes are given wrt value of register E when
when calling the print error message subroutine
print cassette status
at.comment: video buffer address of bottom text line

at.label: io_base
at.header: ---- START memory mapped I/O ----

at.label: io_vid_all
at.header: ---- START video RAM (text + graphics) ----

at.label: io_vid_hires
at.header: ---- START video RAM (graphics only) ----

at.label: rst08_vctr
at.comment:
Call to RST 08H implementation,
by default, a jump to 0x1c96

at.label: rst10_vctr
at.comment:
Call to RST 10H implementation,
by default, a jump to 0x1d78

at.label: rst18_vctr
at.comment:
Call to RST 18H implementation,
by default, a jump to 0x1c90

at.label: rst20_vctr
at.comment:
Call to RST 20H implementation,
by default, a jump to 0x25d9

at.label: rst28_vctr
at.comment:
Call to RST 28H implementation,
by default, "RET"

at.label: rst30_vctr
at.comment:
Call to RST 30H implementation,
by default, "RET"

address of kbd matrix scan subroutine,
usually 0x2ef4

text display mode mask(?)
bits 0, 1, 2, 3, 4: always(?) 0
bit 5 = 0 and bit 6 = 0: bright text on dark back
bit 5 = 1 and bit 6 = 1: dark text on bright back
bit 7: always(?) 0

at.label: curs_addr
at.comment:
memory pointer to video RAM address
of cursor position

when editing, ASCII of least scanned key,
or 0, if no key pressed

at.label: prt_mode
at.comment:
bit 1=0: INVERSE off
bit 1=1: INVERSE on

bit 0=0: cursor off
bit 0=1: cursor on
bit 3=0, bit 6=0: CLOAD in progress
bit 3=1: VERIFY in progress
bit 6=1: CRUN in progress
bit 5=0: direct (sync), fast print into video RAM
bit 5=1: delayed (async), flicker-free print into video RAM

at.label: o_latch_bkp
at.header: copy of output latch
at.comment:
since different I/O devices
(speaker, cassette, CRT control)
share same address, need to remember
status of latch for next write:
* bit 0: speaker membrane status 1
* bit 1: cassette out status 1
* bit 2: cassette out status 2
* bit 3=0: text mode
* bit 3=1: graphics mode
* bit 4=0: green color mode
* bit 4=1: red color mode
* bit 5: speaker membrane status 2

at.label: curs_content
at.comment: video RAM contents at cursor position

at.label: color_mask
at.comment:
color mask for foreground color in text mode:
ccc00000, where ccc is the color
code 0, ..., 7 (for colors 1, ..., 8).

at.label: cb_irq
at.comment:
callback envoked whenever returning from IRQ;
default is a simple "RET", i.e. do nothing

at.label: vect_fn_usr
at.comment:
vector to USR() implementation
default is 0x1e4a, which will
print "?FUNCTION CODE ERROR"

at.label: kbdscan_val
last_err
at.comment:
error code of last error:
* 0x00 NEXT WITHOUT FOR ERROR?
* 0x02 SYNTAX ERROR?
* 0x04 RET'N WITHOUT GOSUB ERROR?
* 0x06 OUT OF DATA ERROR?
* 0x08 FUNCTION CODE ERROR?
* 0x0a OVERFLOW ERROR?
* 0x0c OUT OF MEMORY ERROR?
* 0x0e UNDEF'D STATEMENT ERROR?
* 0x10 BAD SUBSCRIPT ERROR?
* 0x12 REDIM'D ARRAY ERROR?
* 0x14 DIVISION BY ZERO ERROR?
* 0x16 ILLEGAL DIRECT ERROR?
* 0x18 TYPE MISMATCH ERROR?
* 0x1a OUT OF SPACE ERROR?
* 0x1c STRING TOO LONG ERROR?
* 0x1e FORMULA TOO COMPLEX ERROR?
* 0x20 CAN'T CONT ERROR?
* 0x22 NO RESUME ERROR?
* 0x24 RESUME WITHOUT ERROR?
* 0x26 UNPRINTABLE ERROR?
* 0x28 MISSING OPERAND ERROR?
* 0x2a BAD FILE DATA ERROR?
* 0x2c DISK COMMAND SYNTAX ERROR?

at.label: cout_target
at.comment:
currently selected standard output device:
* 0x00 = screen,
* 0x01 = printer,
* 0xff = cassette

at.label: str_var_area
at.comment:
memory pointer to end of basic stack memory /
start of string variable storage area

at.label: curr_line_no
at.comment:
program line number of currently
executed code

at.label: prgmem_start
at.comment: memory pointer to start of BASIC program

at.label: curs_x
at.comment:
current x coordinate of cursor within
current line with 0x00<=x<=0x1f for
single lines or 0x00<=x<=0x3f for
double lines

at.label: parse_in_loc
at.comment:
memory pointer to video RAM address
where to parse INPUT command input values

number of parameters to copy upon
subroutine call(?)

at.label: freemem_top
at.comment:
memory pointer to top of memory /
end of string storage area

at.label: tmp_byte
at.comment:
temporary variable space for e.g.
number of characters to print

at.label: tmp_ptr
at.comment:
temporary pointer to e.g.
memory start address of characters to print

at.label: ram_mem_top
at.comment: memory pointer to RAM upper limit

at.label: edit_line_no
at.comment:
number of least changed BASIC
program line

at.label: lin_proc_buf
at.comment:
memory pointer to buffer (typically at
0x79ee) for processing current program line

at.label: vlt_start
at.comment:
memory pointer to end of BASIC program /
start of simple variables list table ("VLT")

at.label: dim_start
at.comment: memory pointer to start of DIM'd variables list

at.label: var_end
at.comment:
memory pointer to first address behind
variables store

at.label: next_data
at.comment:
memory pointer into BASIC program,
pointing to address directly after DATA value
that has been last read

at.label: var_re-label
at.comment:
used for (re)mapping variable names "A" through "Z"
example: 0x03 in 0x7901 will make variable "A$"
accessible as "A"; default is 0x04

at.label: trace_status
at.comment:
if trace is on, print current line number
while executing BASIC commands
* bit 0=0: NOTRACE, trace off
* bit 0=1: TRACE, trace on

at.label: op_buf
at.comment:
(1) temporary division remainder while
converting 16 bit value into string, or
(2) temporary sum while parsing an
integer number from a string

at.label: tmp_ch_buf
at.comment: temporary character buffer used by PRINT command

at.label: cb_dsk_err1
at.comment:
jump to handler for (hidden) token 0xb0
defaults to a jump to 0x012d, which emits
a (faulty) "?DISK COMMAND ERROR" message

at.label: cb_dsk_err2
at.comment:
jump to handler for (hidden) token 0x85
defaults to a jump to 0x012d, which emits
a (faulty) "?DISK COMMAND ERROR" message

at.label: cb_dsk_err3

jump to handler for (hidden) token 0xa2
defaults to a jump to 0x012d, which emits
a (faulty) "?DISK COMMAND ERROR" message

at.label: cb_dsk_err4

jump to handler for (hidden) token 0xa3
defaults to a jump to 0x012d, which emits
a (faulty) "?DISK COMMAND ERROR" message

at.label: cb_dsk_err5

jump to handler for (hidden) token 0xa4
defaults to a jump to 0x012d, which emits
a (faulty) "?DISK COMMAND ERROR" message

jump to handler for (hidden) token 0xa5
defaults to a jump to 0x012d, which emits
a (faulty) "?DISK COMMAND ERROR" message

at.label: cb_dsk_err7

jump to handler for (hidden) token 0xa6
defaults to a jump to 0x012d, which emits
a (faulty) "?DISK COMMAND ERROR" message

at.label: cb_dsk_err8

jump to handler for (hidden) token 0xa7
defaults to a jump to 0x012d, which emits
a (faulty) "?DISK COMMAND ERROR" message

at.label: cb_dsk_err9
at.comment:
jump to handler for (hidden) token 0xa8
defaults to a jump to 0x012d, which emits
a (faulty) "?DISK COMMAND ERROR" message

at.label: cb_dsk_err10
at.comment:
jump to handler for (hidden) token 0xa9
defaults to a jump to 0x012d, which emits
a (faulty) "?DISK COMMAND ERROR" message

at.label: cb_dsk_err11
at.comment:
jump to handler for (hidden) token 0xaa
defaults to a jump to 0x012d, which emits
a (faulty) "?DISK COMMAND ERROR" message

at.label: cb_dsk_err12
at.comment:
jump to handler for (hidden) token 0xab
defaults to a jump to 0x012d, which emits
a (faulty) "?DISK COMMAND ERROR" message

at.label: cb_dsk_err13
at.comment:
jump to handler for (hidden) token 0xac
defaults to a jump to 0x012d, which emits
a (faulty) "?DISK COMMAND ERROR" message

at.label: cb_dsk_err14
at.comment:
jump to handler for (hidden) token 0xad
defaults to a jump to 0x012d, which emits

at.label: cb_error
at.comment:
callback envoked whenever an error has reported;
default is a simple "RET", i.e. do nothing

at.label: cb_ready
at.comment:
callback envoked whenever "READY" is reported;
default is a simple "RET", i.e. do nothing

at.label: cb_new_line
at.comment:
callback envoked whenever a line has been entered;
default is a simple "RET", i.e. do nothing

at.label: cb_prg_chg1
at.comment:
callback envoked whenever a program line is changed;
default is a simple "RET", i.e. do nothing

at.label: cb_prg_chg2
at.comment:
callback envoked whenever a program line is changed;
default is a simple "RET", i.e. do nothing

at.label: cb_prg_chg3
at.comment:
callback envoked whenever a program line is changed;
default is a simple "RET", i.e. do nothing

at.label: cb_prg_mod
at.comment:
callback envoked whenever a program line is changed,
or RUN or PRINT or CLEAR is executed or an error
message is reported;
default is a simple "RET", i.e. do nothing

at.label: cb_cout
at.comment:
callback envoked whenever printing out a character;
default is a simple "RET", i.e. do nothing

at.label: cb_cmd
at.comment:
callback envoked whenever any BASIC command is executed;
default is a simple "RET", i.e. do nothing

at.label: cb_prt
at.comment:
callback envoked whenever any PRINT command is executed;
default is a simple "RET", i.e. do nothing

at.label: cb_prt_expr
at.comment:
callback envoked whenever any BASIC expression is PRINTed;
default is a simple "RET", i.e. do nothing

at.label: cb_cout_spcl
prg_inp_buf
at.header: ---- START BASIC line input buffer ----

at.label: prg_ln_buf
at.header: ---- working buffer for current BASIC line ----

at.label: fname_buf
at.header:
---- START file name buffer ----
file name buffer for currently processed cassette file,
max. 16 characters + trailing "\0"

at.label: next_crs_x
at.comment:
x coordinate where to place cursor
after next text buffer to screen copy

at.label: cout_buf_avl
at.comment:
current number of bytes available in the
2 text lines print buffer available for
copying into the video RAM upon the next
video gap IRQ for flicker-free display

at.label: cout_scr_adr
at.comment:
pointer to address within screen print
buffer where to put the next char

at.label: cout_buf
at.header:
---- START print buffer ----
2 text lines print buffer available for
copying into the video RAM upon the next
video gap IRQ for flicker-free display

at.label: snd_pitch
at.comment: SOUND pitch of currently played sound

at.label: fname_len
at.comment: file name length of currently handled file

at.label: line_exts
at.header:
---- START line extension flags ----
for each text screen line, remember if
extends onto the next line, thus composing
a double line

at.label: prg_start
at.header: start of memory area for BASIC program text and variables
